conclusion: A child with a mass of 30 kg is sitting on a sled with a mass of 10 kg. An adult pulls the sled with a force of 100 N at an angle of 37° above the horizontal, causing the sled to move at a constant speed along the horizontal ground. Given that sin 37° = 0.6, cos 37° = 0.8, and taking g = 10 m/s².
The total mass of the child and sled is 40 kg.
The weight of the child and sled is 400 N (downward).
The horizontal component of the pulling force is Fₓ = 100 N × 0.8 = 80 N.
The vertical component of the pulling force is Fᵧ = 100 N × 0.6 = 60 N (upward).

premise: Upward forces: normal reaction N + Fᵧ, Downward force: weight W, Equilibrium: N + Fᵧ = W
conclusion: The equation for vertical force balance is N + 60 N = 400 N.
The normal reaction force is N = 400 N – 60 N = 340 N.
The magnitude of the force (often called the “pressure” or normal reaction) exerted by the sled on the ground is N = 3.4 × 10² N ≈ 340 N.
